<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 133, 636, 158]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 183, 194, 213]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 234, 171, 264]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 183, 905, 270]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 287, 324, 304]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 287, 905, 303]]<|/det|>
9231/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 368, 328]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 312, 905, 328]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 337, 905, 352]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 367, 393, 383]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 395, 393, 411]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 228, 445]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 868, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 676, 220, 691]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 693, 728, 725]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 82, 316, 101]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 106, 583, 164]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \left( \begin{array}{ccc}k & 1 & 0\\ 6 & 5 & 2\\ -1 & 3 & -k \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 175, 322, 194]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a real constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 207, 146, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 207, 376, 225]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathbf{A}\) is non-singular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 207, 920, 225]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 185, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 580, 579, 636]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathbf{A}^{-1} = \left( \begin{array}{ccc}3 & 0 & -1\\ 1 & 0 & 0\\ -\frac{23}{2} & \frac{1}{2} & 3 \end{array} \right)\) , find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 592, 920, 611]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 85, 579, 104]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(x^{3} + 2x^{2} + 3x + 1 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 628, 135]]<|/det|>
Find a cubic equation whose roots are \(\alpha^{2} + 1, \beta^{2} + 1, \gamma^{2} + 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 91, 146, 109]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 84, 546, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\left(\alpha^{2} + 1\right)^{3} + \left(\beta^{2} + 1\right)^{3} + \left(\gamma^{2} + 1\right)^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 91, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 528, 181, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 523, 544, 548]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\left(\alpha^{2} + 1\right)^{3} + \left(\beta^{2} + 1\right)^{3} + \left(\gamma^{2} + 1\right)^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 526, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 97, 94, 114]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 482, 123]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \left( \begin{array}{ll}1 & 2\\ 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) \left( \begin{array}{ll}7 & 0\\ 0 & 1 \end{array} \right).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 146, 146]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 848, 147]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations in the \(x\text{-} y\) plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 156, 920, 178]]<|/det|>
Give full details of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 186, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 529, 920, 565]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 594, 695, 615]]<|/det|>
The triangle \(DEF\) in the \(x-y\) plane is transformed by \(\mathbf{M}\) onto triangle \(PQR\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 143, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 751, 644]]<|/det|>
Given that the area of triangle \(PQR\) is \(35 \mathrm{~cm}^2\), find the area of triangle \(DEF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 143, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 81, 660, 101]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for all positive integers \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 106, 608, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r^{2} = \frac{1}{6} n(n + 1)(2n + 1).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 84, 144, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 84, 465, 102]]<|/det|>
The point \((1, 1, 1)\) lies on the plane \(\varPi_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
It is given that the line of intersection of the planes \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\) passes through the point \((0, 0, 2)\) and is parallel to the vector \(\mathbf{i} + 4\mathbf{j} - 3\mathbf{k}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 591, 182]]<|/det|>
Obtain an equation of \(\varPi_{2}\) in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 91, 94, 109]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 84, 416, 112]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x + 1}{x^2 + 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 863, 141]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has no vertical asymptotes and state the equation of the horizontal asymptote. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 186, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 400, 551, 419]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of any stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 400, 918, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 82, 678, 101]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of the intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 438, 144, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 435, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(y^{2} = \frac{x + 1}{x^{2} + 3}\), stating the coordinates of the stationary points and the intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 453, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 82, 418, 101]]<|/det|>
Find the total area enclosed by \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 82, 591, 101]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest distance of a point on \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 114, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 83, 562, 100]]<|/det|>
